translation.title: The Suffering as Conducive to Extinguishment

previous.name: The Impermanent as Conducive to Extinguishment

segments.en: 148. The Suffering as Conducive to Extinguishment
“Mendicants, I will teach you a practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.

segments.pli: katamā ca sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā?
segments.en: And what is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, cakkhuṃ dukkhanti passati, rūpā dukkhāti passati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dukkhanti passati, cakkhusamphasso dukkhoti passati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhanti passati … pe …
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are suffering. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also suffering.
They see that the ear … nose … tongue … body …

segments.pli: mano dukkhoti passati, dhammā dukkhāti passati, manoviññāṇaṃ dukkhanti passati, manosamphasso dukkhoti passati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhanti passati.
segments.en: mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are suffering. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, bhikkhave, nibbānasappāyā paṭipadā”ti.
segments.en: This is that practice that’s conducive to extinguishment.”

suttaplex.blurb: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as suffering.
